slide.title: Determine if a map between vector spaces of polynomials is linear or not.

introduction.p: This is a generic introduction to this section.

statement.p: A linear transformation (also known as a linear map) is a map between vector spaces that preserves the vector space operations.
More precisely, if V and W are vector spaces, a map T:V\rightarrow W is called a linear transformation if

ol.li: T(c\vec{v}) = cT(\vec{v}) for any c \in \IR,\vec{v} \in V.

statement.p: In other words, a map is linear when vector space operations can be applied before or after the transformation without affecting the result.

note.p: Showing L:V\to W is not a linear transformation can be done by finding an example for any one of the following.

ul.li: Show L(\vec z)\not=\vec z (where \vec z is the additive identity of L and W).
Find \vec v,\vec w\in V such that L(\vec v+\vec w)\not=L(\vec v)+L(\vec w).
Find \vec v\in V and c\in \IR such that L(c\vec v)\not=cL(\vec v).

note.p: Otherwise, L can be shown to be linear by proving the following in general.

ul.li: For all \vec v,\vec w\in V, L(\vec v+\vec w)\not=L(\vec v)+L(\vec w).
For all \vec v\in V and c\in \IR, L(c\vec v)\not=cL(\vec v).

note.p: Note the similarities between this process and showing that a subset of a vector space is/isn't a subspace.
